definition: The nominative case of the pronoun of the first person; the word with which a speaker or writer denotes himself.
Materia Medica; that branch of therapeutics which treats of remedies.
An iambus or iambic.
Consisting of a short syllable followed by a long one, or of an unaccented syllable followed by an accented; as, an iambic foot.
Pertaining to, or composed of, iambics; as, an iambic verse; iambic meter. See Lambus.
In a iambic manner; after the manner of iambics.
To satirize in iambics; to lampoon.
A foot consisting of a short syllable followed by a long one, as in &acr;m\'bens, or of an unaccented syllable followed by an accented one, as invent; an iambic. See the Couplet under Iambic, n.
Any gastropod of the genus Ianthina, of which various species are found living in mid ocean; -- called also purple shell, and violet snail.
Of or pertaining to medicine, or to medical men.
Of or pertaining to iatrochemistry, or to the iatrochemists.
A physician who explained or treated diseases upon chemical principles; one who practiced iatrochemistry.

Chemistry applied to, or used in, medicine; -- used especially with reference to the doctrines in the school of physicians in Flanders, in the 17th century, who held that health depends upon the proper chemical relations of the fluids of the body, and who endeavored to explain the conditions of health or disease by chemical principles.
Of or pertaining to iatromathematicians or their doctrine.

One of a school of physicians in Italy, about the middle of the 17th century, who tried to apply the laws of mechanics and mathematics to the human body, and hence were eager student of anatomy; -- opposed to the iatrochemists.
Of or pertaining to Iberia.
One of several species of wild goats having very large, recurved horns, transversely ridged in front; -- called also steinbok.

Any bird of the genus Ibis and several allied genera, of the family Ibid\'91, inhabiting both the Old World and the New. Numerous species are known. They are large, wading birds, having a long, curved beak, and feed largely on reptiles.

Water or other fluid frozen or reduced to the solid state by cold; frozen water. It is a white or transparent colorless substance, crystalline, brittle, and viscoidal. Its specific gravity (0.92, that of water at 4\'f8 C. being 1.0) being less than that of water, ice floats.
To cover with icing, or frosting made of sugar and milk or white of egg; to frost, as cakes, tarts, etc.
Totally surrounded with ice, so as to be incapable of advancing; as, an icebound vessel; also, surrounded by or fringed with ice so as to hinder easy access; as, an icebound coast.
Covered with something resembling ice, as sugar icing; frosted; as, iced cake.
Of or pertaining to Iceland; relating to, or resembling, the Icelanders.
The language of the Icelanders. It is one of the Scandinavian group, and is more nearly allied to the Old Norse than any other language now spoken.

A kind of lichen (Cetraria Icelandica) found from the Arctic regions to the North Temperate zone. It furnishes a nutritious jelly and other forms of food, and is used in pulmonary complaints as a demulcent.
A transparent variety of calcite, the best of which is obtained in Iceland. It is used for the prisms of the polariscope, because of its strong double refraction. Cf. Calcite.
A man who is skilled in traveling upon ice, as among glaciers.
One who deals in ice; one who retails or delivers ice.
Any hymenopterous insect of the family Ichneumonid\'91, of which several thousand species are known, belonging to numerous genera.
A fossil footprint; as, the ichnites in the Triassic sandstone.
A horizontal section of a building or other object, showing its true dimensions according to a geometric scale; a ground plan; a map; also, the art of making such plans.
A fossil footprint; an ichnite.
The branch of science which treats of fossil footprints.
The search for the traces of anything.
An ethereal fluid that supplied the place of blood in the veins of the gods.
A thin, acrid, watery discharge from an ulcer, wound, etc.
Of or like ichor; thin; watery; serous; sanious.
A substance from the egg yolk of osseous fishes.
A nitrogenous substance resembling vitellin, present in the egg yolk of cartilaginous fishes.
A substance from the yolk of salmon's egg.
In early Christian and eccesiastical art, an emblematic fish, or the Greek word for fish, which combined the initials of the Greek words <?/, <?/, <?/ <?/, <?/, Jesus, Christ, Son of God, Savior.
Like, or pertaining to, fishes.
Fish glue; isinglass; a glue prepared from the sounds of certain fishes.
Fossil dung of fishes.
One of the spiny plates foundon the back and tail of certain skates.
A treatise on fishes.
Somewhat like a fish; having some of the characteristics of fishes; -- said of some amphibians.
Worship of fishes, or of fish-shaped idols.
Of or pertaining to ichthyology.
One versed in, or who studies, ichthyology.
The natural history of fishes; that branch of zo\'94logy which relates to fishes, including their structure, classification, and habits.
Divination by the heads or the entrails of fishes.
Fish-shaped; as, the ichthyomorphic idols of ancient Assyria.
One who eats, or subsists on, fish.
Eating, or subsisting on, fish.
The practice of eating, or living upon, fish.
A division of copepod crustaceans, including numerous species parasitic on fishes.
A grand division of the Vertebrata, including the Amphibia and Fishes.
The typical limb, or lateral fin, of fishes.

An extinct genus of toothed birds found in the American Cretaceous formation. It is remarkable for having biconcave vertebr\'91, and sharp, conical teeth set in sockets. Its wings were well developed. It is the type of the order Odontotorm\'91.
One of the Ichthyosaura.
An extinct order of marine reptiles, including Ichthyosaurus and allied forms; -- called also Ichthyopterygia. They have not been found later than the Cretaceous period.
Of or pertaining to the Ichthyosauria.

An extinct genus of marine reptiles; -- so named from their short, biconcave vertebr\'91, resembling those of fishes. Several species, varying in length from ten to thirty feet, are known from the Liassic, O\'94litic, and Cretaceous formations.
A disease in which the skin is thick, rough, and scaly; -- called also fishskin.
One skilled in ichthyotomy.
The anatomy or dissection of fishes.
A pendent, and usually conical, mass of ice, formed by freezing of dripping water; as, the icicles on the eaves of a house.
In an icy manner; coldly.
A coating or covering resembling ice, as of sugar and milk or white of egg; frosting.
An image or representation; a portrait or pretended portrait.
The formation of a figure, representation, or semblance; a delineation or description.
A breaker or destroyer of images or idols; a determined enemy of idol worship.
One who exposes or destroys impositions or shams; one who attacks cherished beliefs; a radical.
Representing by means of pictures or diagrams; as, an icongraphic encyclop\'91dia.
The study of representative art in general.
The worship of images as symbols; -- distinguished from idolatry, the worship of images themselves.
The discussion or description of portraiture or of representative images. Cf. Iconography.
Hostility to images as objects of worship.
Opposed to pictures or images as objects of worship.
Having twenty equal sides or faces.
A solid bounded by twenty sides or faces.
Pertaining to the class Icosandria; having twenty or more stamens inserted in the calyx.
A twenty-four-sided solid; a tetragonal trisoctahedron or trapezohedron.
. A suffix used in forming the names of certain sciences, systems, etc., as acoustics, mathematics, dynamics, statistics, politics, athletics.
Pertaining to, or affected with, jaundice.
Good against the jaundice.
Of a tint resembling that produced by jaundice; yellow; as, an icteroid tint or complexion.
Pertaining to, or caused by, a blow; sudden; abrupt.
A stroke or blow, as in a sunstroke, the sting of an insect, pulsation of an artery, etc.
Characterized by coldness, as of manner, influence, etc.; chilling; frigid; cold.
A small fresh-water cyprinoid fish (Leuciscus idus or Idus idus) of Europe. A domesticated variety, colored like the goldfish, is called orfe in Germany.
Of or pertaining to Idalium, a mountain city in Cyprus, or to Venus, to whom it was sacred.

A suffix used to denote: (a) The nonmetallic, or negative, element or radical in a binary compound; as, oxide, sulphide, chloride. (b) A compound which is an anhydride; as, glycolide, phthalide. (c) Any one of a series of derivatives; as, indogenide, glucoside, etc.
Reaching an imaginary standard of excellence; fit for a model; faultless; as, ideal beauty.
The quality or state of being ideal.
Conception of the ideal; imagery.
One who holds the doctrine of idealism.
The quality or state of being ideal.
The capacity to form ideals of beauty or perfection.
The representation of natural objects, scenes, etc., in such a way as to show their most important characteristics; the study of the ideal.
To treat in an ideal manner. See Idealization, 2.
In an ideal manner; by means of ideals; mentally.
Of or pertaining to an idealogue, or to idealization.
One given to fanciful ideas or theories; a theorist; a spectator.
To form in idea; to fancy.
To apprehend in thought so as to fix and hold in the mind; to memorize.
Uttering sameness or the same truth; expressing in the predicate what is given, or obviously implied, in the subject; tautological.
The quality or state of being identical; sameness.
Capable of being identified.
The act of identifying, or proving to be the same; also, the state of being identified.
To make to be the same; to unite or combine in such a manner as to make one; to treat as being one or having the same purpose or effect; to consider as the same in any relation.
The state or quality of being identical, or the same; sameness.
The condition of being the same with something described or asserted, or of possessing a character claimed; as, to establish the identity of stolen goods.
Of or relating to ideology.
The science which treats of the origin of ideas.
An original, pictorial element of writing; a kind of hieroglyph expressing no sound, but only an idea.
Of or pertaining to an ideogram; representing ideas by symbols, independently of sounds; as, 9 represents not the word "nine," but the idea of the number itself.
The system of writing in ideographic characters; also, anything so written.
The representation of ideas independently of sounds, or in an ideographic manner, as sometimes is done in shorthand writing, etc.
Of or pertaining to ideology.
One who treats of ideas; one who theorizes or idealizes; one versed in the science of ideas, or who advocates the doctrines of ideology.
A theory of the origin of ideas which derives them exclusively from sensation.

Applied to those actions, or muscular movements, which are automatic expressions of dominant ideas, rather than the result of distinct volitional efforts, as the act of expressing the thoughts in speech, or in writing, while the mind is occupied in the composition of the sentence.
An individual cell, differing greatly from its neighbours in regard to size, structure, or contents.
Peculiarity of constitution; that temperament, or state of constitution, which is peculiar to a person; idiosyncrasy.
Peculiar in constitution or temperament; idiosyncratic.
The condition or quality of being an idiot; absence, or marked deficiency, of sense and intelligence.
Electric by virtue of its own peculiar properties; capable of becoming electrified by friction; -- opposed to anelectric.
A mark or signature peculiar to an individual; a trade-mark.
The syntactical or structural form peculiar to any language; the genius or cast of a language.
Having a form of its own.
Apperaing in distinct crystals; -- said of the mineral constituents of a rock.
Pertaining to idiopathy; characterizing a disease arising primarily, and not in consequence of some other disease or injury; -- opposed to symptomatic, sympathetic, and traumatic.
A peculiar, or individual, characteristic or affection.
A morbid state or condition not preceded or occasioned by any other disease; a primary disease.

That portion of the cell protoplasm which is the seat of all active changes, and which carries on the function of hereditary transmission; -- distinguished from the other portion, which is termed nutritive plasma. See Hygroplasm.
A peculiarity of physical or mental constitution or temperament; a characteristic belonging to, and distinguishing, an individual; characteristic susceptibility; idiocrasy; eccentricity.
A man in private station, as distinguished from one holding a public office.
An unlearned, ignorant, or simple person, as distinguished from the educated; an ignoramus.
Pertaining to, or like, an idiot; characterized by idiocy; foolish; fatuous; as, an idiotic person, speech, laugh, or action.
A dictionary of a peculiar dialect, or of the words and phrases peculiar to one part of a country; a glossary.
Like an idiot; foolish.
An idiom; a form, mode of expression, or signification, peculiar to a language.
Lack of knowledge or mental capacity; idiocy; foolishness.
One who idles; one who spends his time in inaction; a lazy person; a sluggard.
One who has constant day duties on board ship, and keeps no regular watch.
An image or representation of anything.
An adorer; a great admirer.
To worship idols; to pay idolatrous worship.
To make in idol of; to idolize.
Of or pertaining to idolatry; partaking of the nature of idolatry; given to idolatry or the worship of false gods; as, idolatrous sacrifices.
Consisting in, or partaking of, an excessive attachment or reverence; as, an idolatrous veneration for antiquity.
The worship of idols, images, or anything which is not God; the worship of false gods.
A worshiper of idols.
To love to excess; to love or reverence to adoration; as, to idolize gold, children, a hero.
A breaker of idols; an iconoclast.
A bituminous substance obtained from the mercury mines of Idria, where it occurs mixed with cinnabar.
Of or pertaining to ancient Idumea, or Edom, in Western Asia.

A short poem; properly, a short pastoral poem; as, the idyls of Theocritus; also, any poem, especially a narrative or descriptive poem, written in an eleveted and highly finished style; also, by extension, any artless and easily flowing description, either in poetry or prose, of simple, rustic life, of pastoral scenes, and the like.
Abbreviation of Latin id est, that is.
In case that; granting, allowing, or supposing that; -- introducing a condition or supposition.
An alkaloid found in nux vomica, and extracted as a white crystalline substance.
An Eskimo snow house.
A cavity, or excavation, made in the snow by a seal, over its breathing hole in the ice.
Pertaining to, having the nature of, fire; containing fire; resembling fire; as, an igneous appearance.
Resulting from, or produced by, the action of fire; as, lavas and basalt are igneous rocks.
A worshiper of fire.
Presiding over fire; also, fiery.
Fig.: A misleading influence; a decoy.
To subject to the action of intense heat; to heat strongly; -- often said of incombustible or infusible substances; as, to ignite iron or platinum.
Capable of being ignited.
The act of igniting, kindling, or setting on fire.
The state of being ignited or kindled.
In an ignoble manner; basely.
Marked with ignominy; in curring public disgrace; dishonorable; shameful.
Public disgrace or dishonor; reproach; infamy.
A stupid, ignorant person; a vain pretender to knowledge; a dunce.
Unacquainted with; unconscious or unaware; -- used with of.
One opposed to the diffusion of knowledge; an obscuriantist.
In a ignorant manner; without knowledge; inadvertently.
To throw out or reject as false or ungrounded; -- said of a bill rejected by a grand jury for want of evidence. See Ignoramus.
Any species of the genus Iguana, a genus of large American lizards of the family Iguanid\'91. They are arboreal in their habits, usually green in color, and feed chiefly upon fruits.

A genus of gigantic herbivorous dinosaurs having a birdlike pelvis and large hind legs with three-toed feet capable of supporting the entire body. Its teeth resemble those of the iguana, whence its name. Several species are known, mostly from the Wealden of England and Europe. See Illustration in Appendix.
Like or pertaining to the genus Iguanodon.
Pertaining to the Iguanid\'91.
A rich, powerful, perfume, obtained from the volatile oil of the flowers of Canada odorata, an East Indian tree.
The peculiar dress worn by pilgrims to Mecca.
Pertaining to the ileum and colon; as, the ileocolic, or ileoc\'91cal, valve, a valve where the ileum opens into the large intestine.
The last, and usually the longest, division of the small intestine; the part between the jejunum and large intestine.
The holm oak (Quercus Ilex).
Pertaining to ancient Ilium, or Troy.
A celebrated Greek epic poem, in twenty-four books, on the destruction of Ilium, the ancient Troy. The Iliad is ascribed to Homer.
The bitter principle of the holly.
A combining form used in anatomy to denote connection with, or relation to, the ilium; as, ilio-femoral, ilio-lumbar, ilio-psoas, etc.
Pertaining to the ilium and femur; as, iliofemoral ligaments.
Pertaining to the iliac and lumbar regions; as, the iliolumbar artery.
The great flexor muscle of the hip joint, divisible into two parts, the iliac and great psoas, -- often regarded as distinct muscles.
The dorsal one of the three principal bones comprising either lateral half of the pelvis; the dorsal or upper part of the hip bone. See Innominate bone, under Innominate.
A yellow dye obtained from the leaves of the holly.
Not lacerable; incapable of being torn or rent.
A snare; a trap.
By inference; as an illative; in an illative manner.
Not laudable; not praise-worthy; worthy of censure or disapprobation.
To make or declare illegal or unlawful.
In a illegal manner; unlawfully.
The state or quality of being illegible.
Incapable of being read; not legible; as, illegible handwriting; an illegible inscription.
The state of being illegitimate.
Unlawfully begotten; born out of wedlock; bastard; as, an illegitimate child.
The act of illegitimating; bastardizing.
The state of being illegitimate; illegitimacy.
Not leviable; incapable of being imposed, or collected.
Indicating a lack of breeding, culture, and the like; ignoble; rude; narrow-minded; disingenuous.
The state or quality of being illiberal; narrowness of mind; meanness; niggardliness.
In a illiberal manner, ungenerously; uncharitably; parsimoniously.
The state of being illiberal; illiberality.
Not permitted or allowed; prohibited; unlawful; as, illicit trade; illicit intercourse; illicit pleasure.
Incapable of being limited or bounded; immeasurable; limitless; boundless; as, illimitable space.
A thin crust of some extraneous substance formed on minerals.
The melting or dissolving of one thing into another.
An instance of ignorance; a literary blunder.
Leading a wicked life.
Having a bad look; threatening; ugly. See Note under Ill, adv.
Dictated by, or indicating, ill nature; spiteful.
Disease; indisposition; malady; disorder of health; sickness; as, a short or a severe illness.
Having unlucky omens; inauspicious. See Note under Ill, adv.
Fated to be unfortunate; unlucky; as, an ill-starred man or day.
Of bad temper; morose; crabbed; sour; peevish; fretful; quarrelsome.
To treat cruelly or improperly; to ill use; to maltreat.
To play upon by artifice; to deceive; to mock; to excite and disappoint the hopes of.
To throw or spread light upon; to make light or bright; to illuminate; to illumine.
That which illuminates or affords light; as, gas and petroleum are illuminants.
To make light; to throw light on; to supply with light, literally or figuratively; to brighten.
To light up; to decorate with artificial lights, as a building or city, in token of rejoicing or respect.
Literally, those who are enlightened; -- variously applied as follows: -
Persons in the early church who had received baptism; in which ceremony a lighted taper was given them, as a symbol of the spiritual illumination they has received by that sacrament.
Festive decoration of houses or buildings with lights.
Tending to illuminate or illustrate; throwing light; illustrative.
A condenser or reflector of light in optical apparatus; also, an illuminant.
One of the Illuminati.
One who, or that which, illuminates.
The principles of the Illuminati.
Of or pertaining to illuminism, or the Illuminati.
To initiate the doctrines or principles of the Illuminati.
An unreal image presented to the bodily or mental vision; a deceptive appearance; a false show; mockery; hallucination.
Hence: Anything agreeably fascinating and charning; enchantment; witchery; glamour.
One given to illusion; a visionary dreamer.
Deceiving by false show; deceitful; deceptive; false; illusory; unreal.
The quality of being illusive; deceptiveness; false show.
Deceiving, or tending of deceive; fallacious; illusive; as, illusory promises or hopes.
To set in a clear light; to exhibit distinctly or conspicuously.
That which illustrates; a comparison or example intended to make clear or apprehensible, or to remove obscurity.
Possessing luster or brightness; brilliant; luminous; splendid.
Characterized by greatness, nobleness, etc.; eminent; conspicuous; distinguished.
The act or operation of smearing the body with mud, especially with the sediment from mineral springs; a mud bath.
One who wishes ill to another; an enemy.
Titanic iron. See Menaccanite.
A supposed element claimed to have been discovered by R.Harmann.
A silicate of iron and lime occurring in black prismatic crystals and columnar masses.
. A contraction of I am.
. A form of the prefix in- not, and in- in. See In-. Im- also occurs in composition with some words not of Latin origin; as, imbank, imbitter.

An imitation, representation, or similitude of any person, thing, or act, sculptured, drawn, painted, or otherwise made perceptible to the sight; a visible presentation; a copy; a likeness; an effigy; a picture; a semblance.
To represent to the mental vision; to form a likeness of by the fancy or recollection; to imagine.
Of or pertaining to an imago.
In a imaginary manner; in imagination.
Existing only in imagination or fancy; not real; fancied; visionary; ideal.
Given to imagining; full of images, fancies, etc.; having a quick imagination; conceptive; creative.
To think; to suppose.
The final adult, and usually winged, state of an insect. See Illust. of Ant-lion, and Army worm.
A Mohammedan prince who, as a successor of Mohammed, unites in his person supreme spiritual and temporal power.
To put under a ban.
The act of surrounding with a bank; a bank or mound raised for defense, a roadway, etc.; an embankment. See Embankment.
To bar in; to secure.
To store in a barn.
To diminish in value.
Destitute of strength, whether of body or mind; feeble; impotent; esp., mentally wea; feeble-minded; as, hospitals for the imbecile and insane.
To weaken; to make imbecile; as, to imbecile men's courage.
Not warlike or martial.
To drink in; to absorb; to suck or take in; to receive as by drinking; as, a person imbibes drink, or a sponge imbibes moisture.
To receive or absorb into the mind and retain; as, to imbibe principles; to imbibe errors.
The act or process of imbibing, or absorbing; as, the post-mortem imbibition of poisons.
The act of imbittering; bitter feeling; embitterment.
To become corporeal; to assume the qualities of a material body. See Embody.
To inclose or place in the midst of; to surround or shelter; as, a house imbosomed in a grove.
Embossed or raised work.
act of imbowing; an arch; a vault.
To entangle as in a cobweb; to mix confusedly.

Lying over each other in regular order, so as to "break joints," like tiles or shingles on a roof, the scales on the leaf buds of plants and the cups of some acorns, or the scales of fishes; overlapping each other at the margins, as leaves in \'91stivation.
An overlapping of the edges, like that of tiles or shingles; hence, intricacy of structure; also, a pattern or decoration representing such a structure.
Cloth of silver or of gold.
A hit or thrust.
A complicated and embarrassing state of things; a serious misunderstanding.
To degrade to the state of a brute; to make brutal.
To tincture deply; to cause to become impressed or penetrated; as, to imbue the minds of youth with good principles.
To supply or stock with money.
The act of imbursing, or the state of being imbursed.
Money laid up in stock.
A dark yellow, crystalline substance, obtained by the action of ammonia on isatin.

A compound with, or derivative of, the imido group; specif., a compound of one or more acid radicals with the imido group, or with a monamine; hence, also, a derivative of ammonia, in which two atoms of hydrogen have been replaced by divalent basic or acid radicals; -- frequently used as a combining form; as, succinimide.
Pertaining to, containing, or combined with, the radical NH, which is called the imido group.
Worthy of imitation; as, imitable character or qualities.
To produce a semblance or likeness of, in form, character, color, qualities, conduct, manners, and the like; to counterfeit; to copy.
That which is made or produced as a copy; that which is made to resemble something else, whether for laudable or for fraudulent purposes; likeness; resemblance.

Inclined to imitate, copy, or follow; imitating; exhibiting some of the qualities or characteristics of a pattern or model; dependent on example; not original; as, man is an imitative being; painting is an imitative art.
Formed after a model, pattern, or original.
The state or office of an imitator.
Without stain or blemish; spotless; undefiled; clear; pure.
To manacle; to fetter; hence; to confine; to restrain from free action.
God with us; -- an appellation of the Christ.
To cover, as with a mask; to disguise or conceal.
Of no substantial consequence; without weight or significance; unimportant; as, it is wholly immaterial whether he does so or not.

The doctrine that external bodies may be reduced to mind and ideas in a mind; any doctrine opposed to materialism or phenomenalism, esp. a system that maintains the immateriality of the soul; idealism; esp., Bishop Berkeley's theory of idealism.
The state or quality of being immaterial or incorporeal; as, the immateriality of the soul.
To render immaterial or incorporeal.
In an unimportant manner or degree.
Premature; untimely; too early; as, an immature death.
In an immature manner.
Incapble of being measured; indefinitely extensive; illimitable; immensurable; vast.
The relation of freedom from the interventionof a medium; immediateness.
Not deferred by an interval of time; present; instant.
Without interval of time; without delay; promptly; instantly; at once.
Not to be healed; incurable.
Not memorable; not worth remembering.
The state of being immense.
Want of worth; demerit.
Immersed; buried; hid; sunk.
Deeply occupied; engrossed; entangled.
Not capable of being immersed.
The act of immersing, or the state of being immersed; a sinking within a fluid; a dipping; as, the immersion of Achilles in the Styx.
Submersion in water for the purpose of Christian baptism, as, practiced by the Baptists.
To catch or entangle in, or as in, the meshes of a net. or in a web; to insnare.
Not methodical; without method or systematic arrangement; without order or regularity; confused.
To render immethodical; to destroy the method of; to confuse.
Not metrical or rhythmical
One who immigrates; one who comes to a country for the purpose of permanent residence; -- correlative of emigrant.
The act of immigrating; the passing or coming into a country for the purpose of permanent residence.
That which is imminent; impending evil or danger.
Full of danger; threatening; menacing; perilous.
To mingle; to mix; to unite; to blend.
Not capable of being mixed or mingled.
To send in; to inject; to infuse; -- the correlative of emit.
To mix; to mingle.
To make immovable; in surgery, to make immovable (a naturally mobile part, as a joint) by the use of splints, or stiffened bandages.
The quality of being immoderate; excess; extravagance.
Not modest; wanting in the reserve or restraint which decorum and decency require; indecent; indelicate; obscene; lewd; as, immodest persons, behavior, words, pictures, etc.
Want of modesty, delicacy, or decent reserve; indecency.
That which is immolated; a sacrifice.
To mold into shape, or form.
An immoral act or practice.
Exemption from oblivion; perpetuity; as, the immortality of fame.
To render immortal; to cause to live or exist forever.
To exempt from oblivion; to perpetuate in fame.
In an immortal manner.
A plant with a conspicuous, dry, unwithering involucre, as the species of Antennaria, Helichrysum, Gomphrena, etc. See Everlasting.
Failure to mortify the passions.
Incapable of being moved; firmly fixed; fast; -- used of material things; as, an immovable foundatin.
Steadfast; fixed; unalterable; unchangeable; -- used of the mind or will; as, an immovable purpose, or a man who remain immovable.

Lands and things adherent thereto by nature, as trees; by the hand of man, as buildings and their accessories; by their destination, as seeds, plants, manure, etc.; or by the objects to which they are applied, as servitudes.
In an immovable manner.

Freedom or exemption from any charge, duty, obligation, office, tax, imposition, penalty, or service; a particular privilege; as, the immunities of the free cities of Germany; the immunities of the clergy.
Freedom; exemption; as, immunity from error.
To inclose whithin walls, or as within walls; hence, to shut up; to imprison; to incarcerate.
An offspring; progeny; child; scion.
To graft with new feathers, as a wing; to splice a broken feather. Hence, Fig.: To repair; to extend; to increase; to strengthen to equip.
The state of being closely surrounded, crowded, or pressed, as by ice.
The single instantaneous stroke of a body in motion against another either in motion or at rest.

An immovable packing; (Med.), a lodgment of something in a strait or passage of the body; as, impaction of the fetal head in the strait of the pelvis; impaction of food or feces in the intestines of man or beast.
One who, or that which, impairs.
The state of being impaired; injury.
To pierce with a pale; to put to death by fixing on a sharp stake. See Empale.
An inclosing by stakes or pales, or the space so inclosed.
To make pallid; to blanch.
Not material; intangible; incorporeal.
To palsy; to paralyze; to deaden.
Embodied in bread, esp. in the bread of the eucharist.

Embodiment in bread; the supposed real presence and union of Christ's material body and blood with the substance of the elements of the eucharist without a change in their nature; -- distinguished from transubstantiation, which supposes a miraculous change of the substance of the elements. It is akin to consubstantiation.
One who holds the doctrine of impanation.
To enter in a list, or on a piece of parchment, called a panel; to form or enroll, as a list of jurors in a court of justice.
To put in a state like paradise; to make supremely happy.
Pinnate with a single terminal leaflet.
Not consisting of an equal number of syllables; as, an imparisyllabic noun, one which has not the same number of syllables in all the cases; as, lapis, lapidis; mens, mentis.
Inequality; disparity; disproportion; difference of degree, rank, excellence, number, etc.
Lack of comparison, correspondence, or suitableness; incongruity.
To have time before pleading; to have delay for mutual adjustment.

Time given to a party to talk or converse with his opponent, originally with the object of effecting, if possible, an amicable adjustment of the suit. The actual object, however, has long been merely to obtain further time to plead, answer to the allegations of the opposite party.
To bestow a share or portion of; to give, grant, or communicate; to allow another to partake in; as, to impart food to the poor; the sun imparts warmth.
To obtain a share of; to partake of.
To hold a conference or consultation.
The act of imparting, or the thing imparted.
Not partial; not favoring one more than another; treating all alike; unprejudiced; unbiased; disinterested; equitable; fair; just.
Not partible; not subject to partition; indivisible; as, an impartible estate.
The quality or condition of being impassible; insusceptibility of injury from external things.
Incapable of suffering; inaccessible to harm or pain; not to be touched or moved to passion or sympathy; unfeeling, or not showing feeling; without sensation.
To move or affect strongly with passion.
Not susceptible of pain or suffering; apathetic; impassible; unmoved.
The act of making into paste; that which is formed into a paste or mixture; specifically, a combination of different substances by means of cements.
To knead; to make into paste; to concrete.
To lay color on canvas by uniting them skillfully together. [R.] Cf. Impasto.
The thickness of the layer or body of pigment applied by the painter to his canvas with especial reference to the juxtaposition of different colors and tints in forming a harmonious whole.

A genus of plants, several species of which have very beautiful flowers; -- so called because the elastic capsules burst when touched, and scatter the seeds with considerable force. Called also touch-me-not, jewelweed, and snapweed.  I. Balsamina (sometimes called lady's slipper) is the common garden balsam.

Not patient; not bearing with composure; intolerant; uneasy; fretful; restless, because of pain, delay, or opposition; eager for change, or for something expected; hasty; passionate; -- often followed by at, for, of, and under.
In an impatient manner.
Absolute seignory or possession; the act of investing with such possession.
To put in pawn; to pledge.
That may be impeached; liable to impeachment; chargeable with a crime.
The act of impeaching, or the state of being impeached
An impelling power or force.
To shut up or inclose, as in a pen.
That property in virtue of which two portions of matter can not at the same time occupy the same portion of space.
In an impenetrable manner or state; imperviously.
The condition of being impenitent; failure or refusal to repent; hardness of heart.
One who is not penitent.
Characterized by short wings covered with feathers resembling scales, as the penguins.
An order of birds, including only the penguins, in which the wings are without quills, and not suited for flight.
Having no wings, as some insects.
To people; to give a population to.
Expressive of command; containing positive command; authoritatively or absolutely directive; commanding; authoritative; as, imperative orders.
Not to be avoided or evaded; obligatory; binding; compulsory; as, an imperative duty or order.
In an imperative manner.

A commander; a leader; an emperor; -- originally an appellation of honor by which Roman soldiers saluted their general after an important victory. Subsequently the title was conferred as a recognition of great military achievements by the senate, whence it carried wiht it some special privileges. After the downfall of the Republic it was assumed by Augustus and his successors, and came to have the meaning now attached to the word emperor.
Of or pertaining to the title or office of imperator.
The state or quality of being imperceptible.
Not perceptible; not to be apprehended or cognized by the souses; not discernible by the mind; not easily apprehended.
Not perfect; not complete in all its parts; wanting a part; deective; deficient.
The state or quality of being imperfectible.
Incapable of being mad perfect.
The quality or condition of being imperfect; want of perfection; incompleteness; deficiency; fault or blemish.
Incapable of being perforated, or bored through.
A division of Foraminifera, including those in which the shell is not porous.
Not perforated; having no opening or aperture.
Of or pertaining to an empire, or to an emperor; as, an imperial government; imperial authority or edict.
The tuft of hair on a man's lower lip and chin; -- so called from the style of beard of Napoleon III.
The act of imperiling, or the state of being imperiled.
Commanding; ascendant; imperial; lordly; majestic.
The quality or state of being imperious; arrogance; haughtiness.
The quality of being impermeable.
Not permeable; not permitting passage, as of a fluid. through its substance; impervious; impenetrable; as, India rubber is impermeable to water and to air.
Not capable of being searched out; inscrutable.
Not persevering; fickle; thoughtless.
Not personal; not representing a person; not having personality.
The quality of being impersonal; want or absence of personality.
In an impersonal manner.
To invest with personality; to endow with the form of a living being.
To ascribe the qualities of a person to; to personify.
One who impersonates; an actor; a mimic.
Want of perspicuity or clearness; vaguness; ambiguity.
Not perspicuous; not clear; obscure; vague; ambeguous.
Not to be persuaded; obstinate; unyielding; impersuasible.
Not persuasible; not to be moved by persuasion; inflexible; impersuadable.
The condition or quality of being impertnent; absence of pertinence, or of adaptedness; irrelevance; unfitness.
Conduct or language unbecoming the person, the society, or the circumstances; rudeness; incivility.
In an impertinent manner.
Incapable of being passed through.
Incapable of being disturbed or disconcerted; as, imperturbable gravity.
In an imperturbable manner; calmly.
The quality of being imperviable.
Not pervious; not admitting of entrance or passage through; as, a substance impervious to water or air.
Of the nature of, or pertaining to, impetigo.
A cutaneous, pustular eruption, not attended with fever; usually, a kind of eczema with pustulation.
Capable of being obtained or moved by petition.
The obtaining of benefice from Rome by solicitation, which benefice belonged to the disposal of the king or other lay patron of the realm.
Vehemence, or furiousnes of temper.
Vehement in feeling; hasty; passionate; violent; as, a man of impetuous temper.
Fig.: Impulse; incentive; vigor; force.
An impious act; an act of wickednes.
The process of repairing broken feathers or a deficient wing.
Striking against or upon.
To fatten; to make fat.
Not pious; wanting piety; irreligious; irreverent; ungodly; profane; wanting in reverence for the Supreme Being; as, an impious deed; impious language.
In the manner of an imp.
The quality or state of being implacable.
Not placable; not to be appeased; incapable of being pacified; inexorable; as, an implacable prince.
In an implacable manner.
Without a placenta, as marsupials and monotremes.
A primary division of the Mammalia, including the monotremes and marsupials, in which no placenta is formed.
To plant, or infix, for the purpose of growth; to fix deeply; to instill; to inculate; to introduce; as, to implant the seeds of virtue, or the principles of knowledge, in the minds of youth.
To cover with plates; to sheathe; as, to implate a ship with iron.
Want of plausibility; the quality of being implausible.
Not plausible; not wearing the appearance of truth or credibility, and not likely to be believed.
To sue at law.
Not admitting excuse, evasion, or plea; rigorous.
To provide with an implement or implements; to cause to be fulfilled, satisfied, or carried out, by means of an implement or implements.
The act of filling, or the state of being full.
That which fills up; filling.
Not pliable; inflexible; inyielding.
To infold; to fold together; to interweave.

To bring into connection with; to involve; to connect; -- applied to persons, in an unfavorable sense; as, the evidence implicates many in this conspiracy; to be implicated in a crime, a discreditable transaction, a fault, etc.
An implying, or that which is implied, but not expressed; an inference, or something which may fairly be understood, though not expressed in words.
By implication; impliedly; as, to deny the providence of God is implicitly to deny his existence.
By implication or inference.
That implores; beseeching; entreating.
A burstion inwards, as of a vessel from which the air has been exhausted; -- contrasted with explosion.

A sudden compression of the air in the mouth, simultaneously with and affecting the sound made by the closure of the organs in uttering p, t, or k, at the end of a syllable (see Guide to Pronunciation, §§159, 189); also, a similar compression made by an upward thrust of the larynx without any accompanying explosive action, as in the peculiar sound of b, d, and g, heard in Southern Germany.
To infold or involve; to wrap up.
To involve in substance or essence, or by fair inference, or by construction of law, when not include virtually; as, war implies fighting.
Not politic; contrary to, or wanting in, policy; unwise; imprudent; indiscreet; inexpedient; as, an impolitic ruler, law, or measure.
The quality of being impolitic.
The quality or state of being imponderable; imponderableness.
Not ponderable; without sensible or appreciable weight; incapable of being weighed.

An imponderable substance or body; specifically, in the plural, a name formely applied to heat, light, electricity, and magnetism, regarded as subtile flyids destitute of weight but in modern science little used.
The quality or state of being imponderable.
To stake; to wager; to pledge.
The state or quality of being imporous; want of porosity; compactness.
To carry or include, as meaning or intention; to imply; to signify.
That which a word, phrase, or document contains as its signification or intention or interpretation of a word, action, event, and the like.
Not to be endured; insupportable; intolerable.
The quality or state of being important; consequence; weight; moment; significance.
Full of, or burdened by, import; charged with great interests; restless; anxious.
The act of carrying, conveying, or delivering.
The act or practice of importing, or bringing into a country or state; -- opposed to exportation.
Troublesomely urgent; unreasonably solicitous; overpressing in request or demand; urgent; teasing; as, an impotunate petitioner, curiosity.
Hard to be borne; unendurable.
Troublesome; vexatious; persistent; urgent; hence, vexatious on account of untimely urgency or perinacious solicitation.
To import; to signify.
The quality of being importunate; pressing or pertinacious solicitation; urgent request; incessant or frequent application; troublesome pertinacity.
Capable of being imposed or laid on.
To lay on; to set or place; to put; to deposit.
Adapted to impress forcibly; impressive; commanding; as, an imposing air; an imposing spectacle.
The quality of being imposing.
The act of imposing, laying on, affixing, enjoining, inflicting, obtruding, and the like.
That which is imposed, levied, or enjoined; charge; burden; injunction; tax.
An impossible thing; that which can not be thought, done, or endured.
The top member of a pillar, pier, wall, etc., upon which the weight of an arch rests.
The act of forming an abscess; state of being inflamed; suppuration.
An abscess; an imposthume.
One who imposes upon others; a person who assumes a character or title not his own, for the purpose of deception; a pretender.
To shut up or place in an inclosure called a pound; hence, to hold in the custody of a court; as, to impound stray cattle; to impound a document for safe keeping.
The fee or fine for impounding.
To make poor; to reduce to poverty or indigence; as, misfortune and disease impoverish families.
To exhaust the strength, richness, or fertility of; to make sterile; as, to impoverish land.
The act of impoverishing, or the state of being impoverished; reduction to poverty.
A pole for supporting a scaffold.
The state or quality of being impracticable; infeasibility.

Not to be overcome, presuaded, or controlled by any reasonable method; unmanageable; intractable; not capable of being easily dealt with; -- used in a general sense, as applied to a person or thing that is difficult to control or get along with.
In an impracticable manner.
To call down by prayer, as something hurtful or calamitous.
To invoke evil upon; to curse; to swear at.
To impregnate; to make fruitful.
Not to be stormed, or taken by assault; incapable of being subdued; able to resist attack; unconquerable; as, an impregnable fortress; impregnable virtue.
To make pregnant; to cause to conceive; to render prolific; to get with child or young.
To come into contact with (an ovum or egg) so as to cause impregnation; to fertilize; to fecundate.

The fusion of a female germ cell (ovum) with a male germ cell (in animals, a spermatozo\'94n) to form a single new cell endowed with the power of developing into a new individual; fertilization; fecundation.
The quality of being imprescriptible.
Not capable of being lost or impaired by neglect, by disuse, or by the claims of another founded on prescription.
Not derived from, or dependent on, external authority; self-evidencing; obvious.
A device. See Impresa.
To produce by pressure, as a mark, stamp, image, etc.; to imprint (a mark or figure upon something).
A mark made by pressure; an indentation; imprint; the image or figure of anything, formed by pressure or as if by pressure; result produced by pressure or influence.
Capable of being impressed; susceptible; sensitive.
The act of impressing, or the state of being impressed; the communication of a stamp, mold, style, or character, by external force or by influence.
That which is impressed; stamp; mark; indentation; sensible result of an influence exerted from without.
Liable or subject to impression; capable of being molded; susceptible; impressible.
The theory or method of suggesting an effect or impression without elaboration of the details; -- a disignation of a recent fashion in painting and etching.
One who adheres to the theory or method of impressionism, so called.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, impressionism.
Having the quality of not being impressed or affected; not susceptible.

Making, or tending to make, an impression; having power to impress; adapted to excite attention and feeling, to touch the sensibilities, or affect the conscience; as, an impressive discourse; an impressive scene.
Capable of being impressed.
The state or quality of being impreventable.
A license to print or publish a book, paper, etc.; also, in countries subjected to the censorship of the press, approval of that which is published.
To impress; to mark by pressure; to indent; to stamp.
To stamp or mark, as letters on paper, by means of type, plates, stamps, or the like; to print the mark (figures, letters, etc., upon something).
To limit, restrain, or confine in any way.
The act of imprisoning, or the state of being imprisoned; confinement; restraint.
Not probable; unlikely to be true; not to be expected under the circumstances or in the usual course of events; as, an improbable story or event.
The act of disapproving; disapprobation.
The act by which falsehood and forgery are proved; an action brought for the purpose of having some instrument declared false or forged.
Lack of probity; want of integrity or rectitude; dishonesty.
Something made or done offhand, at the moment, or without previous study; an extemporaneous composition, address, or remark.
A piece composed or played at first thought; a composition in the style of an extempore piece.
To appropriate to one's self; to assume.
To place the profits of (ecclesiastical property) in the hands of a layman for care and disbursement.
Put into the hands of a layman; impropriated.
The act of impropriating; as, the impropriation of property or tithes; also, that which is impropriated.
The act of putting an ecclesiastical benefice in the hands of a layman, or lay corporation.
The quality of being improper; unfitness or unsuitableness to character, time place, or circumstances; as, improperiety of behavior or manners.
That which is improper; an unsuitable or improper act, or an inaccurate use of language.
The state or quality of being improvable; improvableness.
Capable of being improved; susceptible of improvement; admitting of being made better; capable of cultivation, or of being advanced in good qualities.
To disapprove; to find fault with; to reprove; to censure; as, to improve negligence.
To advance or progress in bad qualities; to grow worse.
Unforeseen; unexpected; not provided against; unprepared.
In a improvident manner.
To improvise; to extemporize.
The act or art of composing and rendering music, poetry, and the like, extemporaneously; as, improvisation on the organ.
That which is improvised; an impromptu.
An improviser, or improvvisatore.
Of or pertaining to improvisation or extemporaneous composition.
To compose, recite, or sing extemporaneously, especially in verse; to extemporize; also, to play upon an instrument, or to act, extemporaneously.
To bring about, arrange, or make, on a sudden, or without previous preparation.

The quality or state of being imprudent; want to caution, circumspection, or a due regard to consequences; indiscretion; inconsideration; reshness; also, an imprudent act; as, he was guilty of an imprudence.
The quality of being impudent; assurance, accompanied with a disregard of the presence or opinions of others; shamelessness; forwardness; want of modesty.
Act of impugning; opposition; attack.
The act of impugning, or the state of being impugned.
The act of impelling, or driving onward with sudden force; impulsion; especially, force so communicated as to produced motion suddenly, or immediately.
The act of impelling or driving onward, or the state of being impelled; the sudden or momentary agency of a body in motion on another body; also, the impelling force, or impulse.
Having the power of driving or impelling; giving an impulse; moving; impellent.
The quality of being impulsive.
One who, or that which, impels; an inciter.
Neglect of, or failure in, punctuality.
Without punishment; with impunity.

Not pure; not clean; dirty; foul; filthy; containing something which is unclean or unwholesome; mixed or impregnated extraneous substances; adulterated; as, impure water or air; impure drugs, food, etc.
The quality or condition of being impure; impurity.
The condition or quality of being impure in any sense; defilement; foulness; adulteration.
That may be imputed; capable of being imputed; chargeable; ascribable; attributable; referable.
The act of imputing or charging; attribution; ascription; also, anything imputed or charged.
To charge; to ascribe; to attribute; to set to the account of; to charge to one as the author, responsible originator, or possessor; -- generally in a bad sense.
A peculiar strong soup or broth, made in Scotland.

A prefix from Eng. prep. in, also from Lat. prep. in, meaning in, into, on, among; as, inbred, inborn, inroad; incline, inject, intrude. In words from the Latin, in- regularly becomes il- before l, ir- before r, and im- before a labial; as, illusion, irruption, imblue, immigrate, impart. In- is sometimes used with an simple intensive force.
An inseparable prefix, or particle, meaning not, non-, un- as, inactive, incapable, inapt. In- regularly becomes il- before l, ir- before r, and im- before a labial.
A suffix. See the Note under -ine.
With reference to space or place; as, he lives in Boston; he traveled in Italy; castles in the air.
One who is in office; -- the opposite of out.
Want of abstinence; indulgence.
The quality or state of being inaccessible; inaccessibleness.
The quality of being inaccurate; want of accuracy or exactness.
Want of action or activity; forbearance from labor; idleness; rest; inertness.
Not active; having no power to move; that does not or can not produce results; inert; as, matter is, of itself, inactive.
The state or quality of being inactive; inertness; as, the inactivity of matter.
To put in action.
Want of adaptation; unsuitableness.
The quality or state of being inadequate or insufficient; defectiveness; insufficiency; inadequateness.
Free; not connected with the other organs.
The state or quality of being inadmissible, or not to be received.
Not admissible; not proper to be admitted, allowed, or received; as, inadmissible testimony; an inadmissible proposition, or explanation.
The quality of being inadvertent; lack of heedfulness or attentiveness; inattention; negligence; as, many mistakes proceed from inadvertence.
Want of affability or sociability; reticence.
Not affable; reserved in social intercourse.
Freedom from affectation; naturalness.
Incapable of being assisted; helpless.
Incapable of being alienated, surrendered, or transferred to another; not alienable; as, in inalienable birthright.
The quality or state of being inalienable; inalienability.
In a manner that forbids alienation; as, rights inalienably vested.
Affording no aliment or nourishment.
Not alterable; incapable of being altered or changed; unalterable.
Incapable of being lost.
A woman in love; a mistress.
Not amovable or removable.
Applied to breeding from a male and female of the same parentage. See under Breeding.
Without contents; empty; void of sense or intelligence; purposeless; pointless; characterless; useless.
That which is void or empty.
Given to talking inanely; loquacious; garrulous.
Infusion of life or vigor; animation; inspiration.

The condition of being inane; emptiness; want of fullness, as in the vessels of the body; hence, specifically, exhaustion from want of food, either from partial or complete starvation, or from a disorder of the digestive apparatus, producing the same result.
Inanition; void space; vacuity; emptiness.
Between ant\'91; -- said of a portico in classical style, where columns are set between two ant\'91, forming the angles of the building. See Anta.
Sensibility; feeling; -- opposed to apathy.
Not admitting of appeal; not appealable.
The quality of being inappellable; finality.
Want of appetency; want of desire.
The quality of being inapplicable; unfitness; inapplicableness.
Not applicable; incapable of being applied; not adapted; not suitable; as, the argument is inapplicable to the case.
Not apposite; not fit or suitable; not pertinent.
Not appreciable; too small to be perceived; incapable of being duly valued or estimated.
Not apprehensible; unintelligible; inconceivable.
Not apprehensive; regardless; unconcerned.
Not instrument (to); not appropriate; unbecoming; unsuitable; not specially fitted; -- followed by to or for.
Unapt; not apt; unsuitable; inept.
Embodied in, or changed into, water.
To graft by uniting, as a scion, to a stock, without separating either from its root before the union is complete; -- also called to graft by approach.
Not uttered with articulation or intelligible distinctness, as speech or words.
In an inarticulate manner.
In like degree; in like manner; seeing that; considering that; since; -- followed by as. See In as much as, under In, prep.
Not audible; incapable of being heard; silent.
Invested with office; inaugurated.
To introduce or induct into an office with suitable ceremonies or solemnities; to invest with power or authority in a formal manner; to install; as, to inaugurate a president; to inaugurate a king.
The act of inuagurating, or inducting into office with solemnity; investiture by appropriate ceremonies.
Suitable for, or pertaining to, inauguration.
To cover with gold; to gild.
The act or process of gilding or covering with gold.
To embark; to go or put into a barge.
Inside the line of a vessel's bulwarks or hull; the opposite of outboard; as, an inboard cargo; haul the boom inboard.
From without inward; toward the inside; as, the inboard stroke of a steam engine piston, the inward or return stroke.
To infuse by breathing; to inspire.
To produce or generate within.
A Japanese measure of length equal to about two and one twelfth yards.
An emperor or monarch of Peru before, or at the time of, the Spanish conquest; any member of this royal dynasty, reputed to have been descendants of the sun.
Not capable of being calculated; beyond calculation; very great.
The state of being incalescent, or of growing warm.
The act or process of uniting lands, rights, or revenues, to the ecclesiastical chamber, i. e., to the pope's domain.
Of or pertaining to the Incas.
A white heat, or the glowing or luminous whiteness of a body caused by intense heat.
White, glowing, or luminous, with intense heat; as, incandescent carbon or platinum; hence, clear; shining; brilliant.
Hoary with white pubescence.
The act or process of using formulas sung or spoken, with occult ceremonies, for the purpose of raising spirits, producing enchantment, or affecting other magical results; enchantment.
Want of legal qualifications, or of legal power; as, incapability of holding an office.

Wanting in ability or qualification for the purpose or end in view; not large enough to contain or hold; deficient in physical strength, mental or moral power, etc.; not capable; as, incapable of holding a certain quantity of liquid; incapable of endurance, of comprehension, of perseverance, of reform, etc.
The quality or state of being incapable; incapability.
In an incapable manner.
Not capacious; narrow; small; weak or foolish; as, an incapacious soul.
To deprive of capacity or natural power; to disable; to render incapable or unfit; to disqualify; as, his age incapacitated him for war.
Want of capacity; lack of physical or intellectual power; inability.
The process of becoming, or the state or condition of being, incapsulated; as, incapsulation of the ovum in the uterus.
To imprison; to confine in a jail or priso<?/.
The act of confining, or the state of being confined; imprisonment.
To cover or invest with flesh.
Invested with flesh; embodied in a human nature and form; united with, or having, a human body.
The act of clothing with flesh, or the state of being so clothed; the act of taking, or being manifested in, a human body and nature.
The act of assuming, or state of being clothed with, flesh; incarnation.
To inclose in a case; to inclose; to cover or surround with something solid.
The act or process of inclosing with a case, or the state of being incased.
Act of making hollow; also, a hollow; an exvation; a depression.
Inclosed in a cave.
Inclosed or shut up as in a cavern.
Any person who maliciously sets fire to a building or other valuable or other valuable property.
Of or pertaining to incendiarism, or the malicious burning of valuable property; as, incendiary material; as incendiary crime.
A modern term applied to animals (as a boar) when borne as raging, or with furious aspect.
The offering of incense.
To set on fire; to inflame; to kindle; to burn.
To offer incense to. See Incense.
The perfume or odors exhaled from spices and gums when burned in celebrating religious rites or as an offering to some deity.
Represented as enraged, as any wild creature depicted with fire issuing from mouth and eyes.
The act of kindling, or the state of being kindled or on fire.
The vessel in which incense is burned and offered; a censer; a thurible.
The center of the circle inscribed in a triangle.
Inciting; encouraging or moving; rousing to action; stimulative.
An inceptive word, phrase, or clause.
A beginner; one in the rudiments.
One who is on the point of taking the degree of master of arts at an English university.
The quality of being incessant; unintermitted continuance; unceasingness.

A measure of length, the twelfth part of a foot, commonly subdivided into halves, quarters, eights, sixteenths, etc., as among mechanics. It was also formerly divided into twelve parts, called lines, and originally into three parts, called barleycorns, its length supposed to have been determined from three grains of barley placed end to end lengthwise. It is also sometimes called a prime (\'b7), composed of twelve seconds (\'b7\'b7), as in the duodecimal system of arithmetic.
To drive by inches, or small degrees.
A piece an inch long.
Recently, or just, begun; beginning; partially but not fully in existence or operation; existing in its elements; incomplete.
The sweetbread of a deer.
To cut; to separate and remove; to resolve or break up, as by medicines.
A falling on or upon; an incident; an event.
Falling or striking upon, as a ray of light upon a reflecting surface.
That which falls out or takes place; an event; casualty; occurrence.
Capable of being incinerated or reduced to ashes.
Beginning to be, or to show itself; commencing; initial; as, the incipient stage of a fever; incipient light of day.
To cut in or into with a sharp instrument; to carve; to engrave.
Having deep and sharp notches, as a leaf or a petal.
The act of incising, or cutting into a substance.
Having the quality of incising, cutting, or penetrating, as with a sharp instrument; cutting; hence, sharp; acute; sarcastic; biting.
Adapted for cutting; of or pertaining to the incisors; incisive; as, the incisor nerve; an incisor foramen; an incisor tooth.
Having the quality of cutting; incisor; incisive.
A cut; an incision; a gash.
That which incites; an inciting agent or cause; a stimulant.
The act of inciting or moving to action.
The act of inciting.
So as to incite or stimulate.
Inciting to motion; -- applied to that action which, in the case of muscular motion, commences in the nerve centers, and excites the muscles to contraction. Opposed to excito-motor.
The quality or state of being uncivil; want of courtesy; rudeness of manner; impoliteness.
The state or quality of being inclement; want of clemency; want of mildness of temper; unmercifulness; severity.
Not clement; destitute of a mild and kind temper; void of tenderness; unmerciful; severe; harsh.
The act of inclining, or state of being inclined; a leaning; as, an inclination of the head.
To deviate from a line, direction, or course, toward an object; to lean; to tend; as, converging lines incline toward each other; a road inclines to the north or south.
To impart a tendency or propensity to, as to the will or affections; to turn; to dispose; to influence.
Having a leaning or tendency towards, or away from, a thing; disposed or moved by wish, desire, or judgment; as, a man inclined to virtue.
Making an angle with some line or plane; -- said of a line or plane.
Same as Inclined, 3.
Party or side chosen; a following.
To clasp; to inclose.
To surround; to shut in; to confine on all sides; to include; to shut up; to encompass; as, to inclose a fort or an army with troops; to inclose a town with walls.
The act of inclosing; the state of being inclosed, shut up, or encompassed; the separation of land from common ground by a fence.
To confine within; to hold; to contain; to shut up; to inclose; as, the shell of a nut includes the kernel; a pearl is included in a shell.
A tribe of bivalve mollusks, characterized by the closed state of the mantle which envelops the body. The ship borer (Teredo navalis) is an example.
The act of including, or the state of being included; limitation; restriction; as, the lines of inclusion of his policy.
To put a coach.
The state of not coalescing.
Not to be coerced; incapable of being compelled or forced.
Not cogitative; not thinking; wanting the power of thought; as, a vegetable is an incogitative being.
A woman who is unknown or in disguise.
Without being known; in disguise; in an assumed character, or under an assumed title; -- said esp. of great personages who sometimes adopt a disguise or an assumed character in order to avoid notice.
One unknown or in disguise, or under an assumed character or name.
The quality or state of being incoherent; want of coherence; want of cohesion or adherence.
Not coherent; wanting cohesion; loose; unconnected; physically disconnected; not fixed to each; -- said of material substances.
In an incoherent manner; without due connection of parts.
The quality of being incoincident; want of coincidence.
Not coincident; not agreeing in time, in place, or principle.
To be incapable of combining; to disagree; to differ.
Not combustible; not capable of being burned, decomposed, or consumed by fire; uninflammable; as, asbestus is an incombustible substance; carbon dioxide is an incombustible gas.
One who succeeds another, as a tenant of land, houses, etc.
Coming in, succeeding, or following, as occupant or possessor; as, in incoming tenant.
See Commendam, and Partnership in Commendam, under Partnership.
The quality or state of being incommensurable.
Not commensurate; not admitting of a common measure; incommensurable.
Not of equal of sufficient measure or extent; not adequate; as, our means are incommensurate to our wants.
A state of being unmixed; separateness.
To give inconvenience or trouble to; to disturb or molest; to discommode; to worry; to put out; as, we are incommoded by want of room.
Inconvenience; trouble; annoyance; disadvantage; encumbrance.
Not communicable; incapable of being communicated, shared, told, or imparted, to others.
Not commutable; not capable of being exchanged with, or substituted for, another.
Not compact; not having the parts firmly united; not solid; incoherent; loose; discrete.
Want of compassion or pity.
The quality or state of being incompatible; inconsistency; irreconcilableness.

Not compatible; so differing as to be incapable of harmonious combination or coexistence; inconsistent in thought or being; irreconcilably disagreeing; as, persons of incompatible tempers; incompatible colors, desires, ambition.
The quality or state of being incompatible; incompatibility.
In an incompatible manner; inconsistently; incongruously.

The quality or state of being incompetent; want of physical, intellectual, or moral ability; insufficiency; inadequacy; as, the incompetency of a child hard labor, or of an idiot for intellectual efforts.
Not competent; wanting in adequate strength, power, capacity, means, qualifications, or the like; incapable; unable; inadequate; unfit.
Not complete; not filled up; not finished; not having all its parts, or not having them all adjusted; imperfect; defective.
The state of being incomplete; imperfectness; defectiveness.
The quality or state of being incompliant; unyielding temper; obstinacy.
Refusal or failure to comply.
Not composite; uncompounded; simple.
Not capable of being contained within limits.
The quality of being incompressible, or incapable of reduction in volume by pressure; -- formerly supposed to be a property of liquids.

Not conclusive; leading to no conclusion; not closing or settling a point in debate, or a doubtful question; as, evidence is inconclusive when it does not exhibit the truth of a disputed case in such a manner as to satisfy the mind, and put an end to debate or doubt.
Imperfectly digested, matured, or ripened.
The quality or state of being incondensable.
Not condensable; incapable of being made more dense or compact, or reduced to liquid form.
Badly put together; inartificial; rude; unpolished; irregular.
Want of conformity; nonconformity.
Freedom from confusion; distinctness.
The quality or state of being incongruous; want of congruity; unsuitableness; inconsistency; impropriety.
Not connectedly; without connection.
The state or quality of not being consecutive.
The state of being inconsequential.
Not considerable; unworthy of consideration or notice; unimportant; small; trivial; as, an inconsiderable distance; an inconsiderable quantity, degree, value, or sum.

Not considerate; not attentive to safety or to propriety; not regarding the rights or feelings of others; hasty; careless; thoughtless; heedless; as, the young are generally inconsiderate; inconsiderate conduct.
The quality or state of being inconsiderate.

The quality or state of being inconsistent; discordance in respect to sentiment or action; such contrariety between two things that both can not exist or be true together; disagreement; incompatibility.
Not consistent; showing inconsistency; irreconcilable; discordant; at variance, esp. as regards character, sentiment, or action; incompatible; incongruous; contradictory.
Not consolable; incapable of being consoled; grieved beyond susceptibility of comfort; disconsolate.
Not consonant or agreeing; inconsistent; discordant.
Not conspicuous or noticeable; hardly discernible.
Not consumable; incapable of being consumed, wasted, or spent.
Not consummated; not finished; incomplete.
Not contestable; not to be disputed; that cannot be called in question or controverted; incontrovertible; indisputable; as, incontestable evidence, truth, or facts.

Incapacity to hold; hence, incapacity to hold back or restrain; the quality or state of being incontinent; want of continence; failure to restrain the passions or appetites; indulgence of lust; lewdness.
Not continent; uncontrolled; not restraining the passions or appetites, particularly the sexual appetite; indulging unlawful lust; unchaste; lewd.
Immediately; at once; forthwith.
Not controvertible; too clear or certain to admit of dispute; indisputable.
The quality or condition of being inconvenient; want of convenience; unfitness; unsuitableness; inexpediency; awkwardness; as, the inconvenience of the arrangement.
Not becoming or suitable; unfit; inexpedient.
Not conversant; not acquainted; not versed; unfamiliar.
Not turned or changed about.
Not convertible; not capable of being transmuted, changed into, or exchanged for, something else; as, one metal is inconvertible into another; bank notes are sometimes inconvertible into specie.
In an inconvertible manner.
Not convincible; incapable of being convinced.
Unlearned; artless; pretty; delicate.
Want of co\'94rdination; lack of harmonious adjustment or action.
Not consisting of matter; not having a material body; incorporeal; spiritual.
To form into a body; to combine, as different ingredients. into one consistent mass.
The act of incorporating, or the state of being incorporated.
Not corporeal; not having a material body or form; not consisting of matter; immaterial.
Not correct; not according to a copy or model, or to established rules; inaccurate; faulty.
The quality of being incorrect; want of conformity to truth or to a standard; inaccuracy; inexactness; as incorrectness may in defect or in redundance.
Want of correspondence; disagreement; disproportion.
Incapable of being corroded, consumed, or eaten away.
Not affected with corruption or decay; unimpaired; not marred or spoiled.
Not corruptible; incapable of corruption, decay, or dissolution; as, gold is incorruptible.
The quality or state of being incorruptible.
The condition or quality of being incorrupt or incorruptible; absence of, or exemption from, corruption.
Made thick or thicker; thickened; inspissated.
The act or process of thickening or making thick; the process of becoming thick or thicker.
To become greater or more in size, quantity, number, degree, value, intensity, power, authority, reputation, wealth; to grow; to augment; to advance; -- opposed to decrease.
Addition or enlargement in size, extent, quantity, number, intensity, value, substance, etc.; augmentation; growth.
The quality or state of being incredible; incredibleness.
In an incredible manner.
The state or quality of being i<?/credulous; a withholding or refusal of belief; skepticism; unbelief; disbelief.
Not credulous; indisposed to admit or accept that which is related as true, skeptical; unbelieving.
Incapable of being burnt; incombustibe.
Burning; esp., the act of burning a dead body; cremation.
The act or process of increasing; growth in bulk, guantity, number, value, or amount; augmentation; enlargement.
To chide; to rebuke; to reprove.
A chiding; rebuke; reproof.
Increasing; growing; augmenting; swelling; enlarging.
The act of incriminating; crimination.
Of or pertaining to crimination; tending to incriminate; criminatory.
Unbloody; not attended with blood; as, an incruental sacrifice.
To cover or line with a crust, or hard coat; to form a crust on the surface of; as, iron incrusted with rust; a vessel incrusted with salt; a sweetmeat incrusted with sugar.
The act of incrusting, or the state of being incrusted.
Not crystallizable; incapable of being formed into crystals.
To sit, as on eggs for hatching; to brood; to brood upon, or keep warm, as eggs, for the purpose of hatching.
A sitting on eggs for the purpose of hatching young; a brooding on, or keeping warm, (eggs) to develop the life within, by any process.
That which incubates, especially, an apparatus by means of which eggs are hatched by artificial heat.
To fix firmly, as in cube; to secure or place firmly.
A demon; a fiend; a lascivious spirit, supposed to have sexual intercourse with women by night.
Untilled; uncultivated; crude; rude; uncivilized.
The state of being incumbent; a lying or resting on something.
Lying; resting; reclining; recumbent; superimposed; superincumbent.
A burdensome and troublesome load; anything that impedes motion or action, or renders it difficult or laborious; clog; impediment; hindrance; check.

To meet or fall in with, as something inconvenient, harmful, or onerous; to put one's self in the way of; to expose one's self to; to become liable or subject to; to bring down upon one's self; to encounter; to contract; as, to incur debt, danger, displeasure
Not capable of being cured; beyond the power of skill or medicine to remedy; as, an incurable disease.
The state of being incurable; incurability.
Characterized by a current which flows inward; as, the incurrent orifice of lamellibranch Mollusca.
A running into; hence, an entering into a territory with hostile intention; a temporary invasion; a predatory or harassing inroad; a raid.
The act of bending, or curving.
Bending gradually toward the axis or center, as branches or petals.
A state of being bent or curved; incurvation; a bending inwards.
To strike or stamp in.
A nitrogenous compound, C7H6N2, analogous to indol, and produced from a diazo derivative or cinnamic acid.
Azure-colored; of a bright blue color.
To bring into debt; to place under obligation; -- chiefly used in the participle indebted.
The sum owed; debts, collectively.
The quality or state of being indecent; want of decency, modesty, or good manners; obscenity.
Having no decidua; nondeciduate.
Want of decision; want of settled purpose, or of firmness; indetermination; wavering of mind; irresolution; vacillation; hesitation.
Not decisive; not bringing to a final or ultimate issue; as, an indecisive battle, argument, answer.
The state of being indecisive; unsettled state.
Not declinable; not varied by inflective terminations; as, nihil (nothing), in Latin, is an indeclinable noun.
Without variation of termination.
Incapableness of decomposition; stability; permanence; durability.
Not decorous; violating good manners; contrary to good breeding or etiquette; unbecoming; improper; out of place; as, indecorous conduct.
The quality of being indecorous; want of decorum.
Want of decorum; impropriety of behavior; that in behavior or manners which violates the established rules of civility, custom, or etiquette; indecorousness.
Incapable of being fatigued; not readily exhausted; unremitting in labor or effort; untiring; unwearying; not yielding to fatigue; as, indefatigable exertions, perseverance, application.
Not to be defeated; not defeasible; incapable of being annulled or made void; as, an indefeasible or title.
The quality or state of not being defensible.
Not definite; not limited, defined, or specified; not explicit; not determined or fixed upon; not precise; uncertain; vague; confused; obscure; as, an indefinite time, plan, etc.
Indefiniteness; vagueness; also, number or quantity not limited by our understanding, though yet finite.
Remaining closed at maturity, or not opening along regular lines, as the acorn, or a cocoanut.
Not delectable; unpleasant; disagreeable.
The quality of being indelible.
That can not be removed, washed away, blotted out, or effaced; incapable of being canceled, lost, or forgotten; as, indelible characters; an indelible stain; an indelible impression on the memory.
To save harmless; to secure against loss or damage; to insure.
Security; insurance; exemption from loss or damage, past or to come; immunity from penalty, or the punishment of past offenses; amnesty.
Incapable of being demonstrated.
The act of naturalizing; endenization.
To invest with the privileges of a denizen; to naturalize.
To notch; to jag; to cut into points like a row of teeth; as, to indent the edge of paper.
To crook or turn; to wind in and out; to zigzag.
A stamp; an impression.
A notch or recess, in the margin or border of anything; as, the indentations of a leaf, of the coast, etc.
Having an uneven, irregular border; sinuous; undulating.
Indentation; an impression like that made by a tooth.
Same as Indentation, 4.
The act of indenting, or state of being indented.
To indent; to make hollows, notches, or wrinkles in; to furrow.

The state or quality of being independent; freedom from dependence; exemption from reliance on, or control by, others; self-subsistence or maintenance; direction of one's own affairs without interference.
Not dependent; free; not subject to control by others; not relying on others; not subordinate; as, few men are wholly independent.
One who does not acknowledge an obligation to support a party's candidate under all circumstances; one who exercises liberty in voting.
Incapable of being deposed.
Incapable of being described.
The quality of being indestructible.
Not destructible; incapable of decomposition or of being destroyed.
Not determinable; impossible to be determined; not to be definitely known, ascertained, defined, or limited.
An indeterminable thing or quantity.
Want of determination; an unsettled or wavering state, as of the mind.
That which points out; that which shows, indicates, manifests, or discloses.
One who makes an index.
Of, pertaining to, or like, an index; having the form of an index.
In the manner of an index.
Want of dexterity or readiness, especially in the use of the hands; clumsiness; awkwardness.
A large vessel in the India trade.
Of or pertaining to India proper; also to the East Indies, or, sometimes, to the West Indies.
One of the aboriginal inhabitants of America; -- so called originally from the supposed identity of America with India.

A glucoside obtained from woad (indigo plant) and other plants, as a yellow or light brown sirup. It has a nauseous bitter taste, a decomposes or drying. By the action of acids, ferments, etc., it breaks down into sugar and indigo. It is the source of natural indigo.
That which indicates or points out; as, an indicant of the remedy for a disease.
To point out; to discover; to direct to a knowledge of; to show; to make known.
Act of pointing out or indicating.
Pointing out; bringing to notice; giving intimation or knowledge of something not visible or obvious.
In an indicative manner; in a way to show or signify.
One who, or that which, shows or points out; as, a fare indicator in a street car.

A certain conic section supposed to be drawn in the tangent plane to any surface, and used to determine the accidents of curvature of the surface at the point of contact. The curve is similar to the intersection of the surface with a parallel to the tangent plane and indefinitely near it. It is an ellipse when the curvature is synclastic, and an hyperbola when the curvature is anticlastic.
A writ of prohibition against proceeding in the spiritual court in certain cases, when the suit belongs to the common-law courts.
Discriminating marks; signs; tokens; indications; appearances.
A variety of tourmaline of an indigo-blue color.
To write; to compose; to dictate; to indite.
Declaration; proclamation; public notice or appointment.
The act of indicting, or the state of being indicted.
